speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon, and welcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We decided today to lower the target for the federal funds rate by ¼ percentage point to a range of 2 percent to 2¼ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The outlook for the U.S. economy remains favorable, and this action is designed to support that outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is intended to insure against downside risks from weak global growth and trade policy uncertainty, to help offset the effects these factors are currently having on the economy, and to promote a faster return of inflation to our symmetric 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of these objectives will support achievement of our overarching goal: to sustain the expansion, with a strong job market and inflation close to our objective, for the benefit of the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also decided to conclude the runoff of our securities portfolio in August rather than in September, as previously planned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ll discuss the thinking behind today’s interest rate reduction and then turn to the path forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the year began, both the economy and monetary policy were in a good place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate was below 4 percent, and inflation had been running near our 2 percent objective for nine months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our interest rate target was at the low end of estimates of neutral.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the first half of the year, the economy grew at a healthy pace and job gains pushed unemployment to near a half-century low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Wages have been rising, particularly for lower-paying jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People who live and work in low- and middle-income communities tell us that many who have struggled to find work are now getting opportunities to add new and better chapters to their lives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This underscores for us the importance of sustaining the expansion so that the strong job market reaches more of those left behind.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Through the course of the year, weak global growth, trade policy uncertainty, and muted inflation have prompted the FOMC to adjust its assessment of the appropriate path of interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Committee moved from expecting rate increases this year to a patient stance about any changes and then to today’s action.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median Committee participant’s assessments of the neutral rate of interest and the longer-run normal rate of unemployment have also declined this year, reinforcing the case for a somewhat lower path for our policy rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These changes in the anticipated path of interest rates have eased financial conditions and have supported the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At our June meeting, many Committee participants saw that the case for lowering the federal funds rate had strengthened, but the Committee wanted to get a better sense of the overall direction of events.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since then, we have seen both positive and negative developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Job growth was strong in June and, looking through month-to-month fluctuations, the data point to continued strength.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect job growth to be slower than last year but above what we believe is required to hold the unemployment rate steady.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: GDP growth in the second quarter came in close to expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Consumption—supported by rising incomes and high household confidence—is the main engine driving the economy forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But manufacturing output has declined for two consecutive quarters, and business fixed investment fell in the second quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Foreign growth has disappointed, particularly in manufacturing and notably in the euro area and China.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In response to this weakness, many central banks around the world are increasing policy accommodation or contemplating doing so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: After simmering early in the year, trade policy tensions nearly boiled over in May and June but now appear to have returned to a simmer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking through this July 31, 2019 variability, our business contacts tell us that the ongoing uncertainty is making some companies Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL more cautious about their capital spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The domestic inflation shortfall has continued.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Core inflation, which excludes food and energy prices and is a better gauge of future developments than is total inflation, has run at 1.6 percent over the past 12 months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We continue to expect that inflation will return over time to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But domestic inflation pressures remain muted, and global disinflationary pressures persist.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Wages are rising, but not at a pace that would put much upward pressure on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are mindful that inflation’s return to 2 percent may be further delayed, and that continued below-target inflation could lead to a worrisome and difficult-to-reverse downward slide in longer-term expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So taking all of that on board, the Committee still sees a favorable baseline outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the year, however, incoming information on global growth, trade policy uncertainty, and muted inflation have led the Committee to gradually lower its assessments of the path of policy interest rate that would best support that outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today, we judge that those factors warrant the policy adjustment I described: “As the Committee contemplates the future path of the target range for the federal funds rate, it will continue to monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook and will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near its symmetric 2 percent objective.” Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I am happy to take your questions.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Jeanna Smialek with the New York Times.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Per your statement here, I guess the question is, is there any reason to believe that a 25 basis point cut is going to be sufficient to expediently return inflation to your 2 percent target?

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: And, if not, July 31, 2019 what are you going to be looking at to convince you that you need to cut rates again?

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: What is Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the hurdle rate there?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think you have to look at not just the 25 basis point cut, but look at the Committee’s actions over the course of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I noted in my opening statement, we started off expecting some rate increases, we moved to a patient setting for a few months, and now we’ve moved here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think what you’ve seen over the course of the year is, as we’ve moved to a more accommodative policy, the economy has actually performed just about as expected with that gradually increasing support.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think—I wouldn’t take credit for all of that, but I do think that increasing policy support has kept the economy on track and kept the outlook favorable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the rest of your question, the Committee is really thinking of this as a way of adjusting policy to a somewhat more accommodative stance to further the three objectives that I mentioned: to insure against downside risks, to provide support to the economy, that those factors are—where factors are pushing down on economic growth, and then to support inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we do think it will serve all of those goals, but again, we’re thinking of it as essentially in the nature of a midcycle adjustment to policy.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Michael McKee from Bloomberg Television and Radio.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: There’s a perception out there that perhaps, in this case, the Fed is something of a hammer in search of a nail, because the latest consumer spending reports, as you suggested, don’t seem to show any kind of demand problem in the U.S. And when you look at mortgage rates, auto lending rates, they’ve all come down.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: And so, wondering exactly what problem lower capital costs will solve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you’re absolutely right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The—the performance of the economy has been reasonably good.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The position of the economy is as close to our objectives as it’s been July 31, 2019 in a long time, and the outlook is also good.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we’ve been monitoring since the beginning of Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the year is, effectively, downside risks to that outlook from weakening global growth, and we see that everywhere: weak manufacturing, weak global growth now, particularly in the European Union and China.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, we see trade policy developments, which at times have been disruptive and then have been less so, and also inflation running below target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we see those as threats to what is clearly a favorable outlook, and we see this action as designed to support them and keep that outlook favorable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, frankly, it is a continuation of what we’ve been doing all year to provide more support against those very same risks.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: But the follow-up question is, how does it do that?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: How does cutting interest rates lower—or, how does cutting interest rates keep that going, since the cost of capital doesn’t seem to be the issue here?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I—I really think it does, and I think the evidence of my eyes tells me that our policy does support—it supports confidence, it supports economic activity, household and business confidence, and through channels that we understand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it will lower borrowing costs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will—and it will work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think you see it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since—you know, since we noted our vigilance about the situation in June, you saw financial conditions move up, and you saw—I won’t take credit for the whole recovery, but you saw financial conditions move up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see confidence, which had troughed in June—you saw it move back up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see economic activity on a healthy basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It just—it seems to work through confidence channels as well as the mechanical channels that you are talking about.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Hi, Heather Long from the Washington Post.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: You always say that the Fed is data dependent, and much of the data that we’ve seen since the June meeting has surprised to the upside or at least been in line with expectations.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Can you give us a sense of how July 31, 2019 that better-than-expected data impacted the FOMC’s thinking?

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: And if we keep seeing these Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL upside surprises, does that change or evolve any FOMC thinking going forward?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I think we—of course, you know, what we do at every meeting, as I noted, is, we do a deep dive into U.S. economic activity and global activity and, certainly, carefully went through U.S. economic activity, which there has been some positive and some negative, but, overall, the U.S. economy has shown resilience during the intermeeting period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, again, the—the issue is more the downside risks and then the shortfall in inflation, and we’re trying to address those.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in addition, going forward, I would say, we’re going to be monitoring those same things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be monitoring the evolution of trade uncertainty, of global growth, and of low inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll also, of course, be watching the performance of the U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, it had shown some resilience here to those issues, and we’ll be putting all of that together, and that’s how we’ll be thinking about policy going forward.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Steve Liesman, CNBC.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I just want to follow up on that.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Would you say we’re sort of—you guys have gotten into a new regime here?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: This is sort of an insurance cut and not a data-dependent cut?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: And are we now more in the realm of watching headlines of trade talks than we are watching unemployment rate and inflation numbers, or—and growth numbers?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: What—how do we know what you’re going to do next, and why now in this new regime?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I gave three reasons for what we did, and that is to insure against downside risks to the outlook from weak global growth and trade tensions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that is—in a sense, that is a risk-management point, and that is a bit of insurance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we also feel like weak global growth and trade tensions are having an effect on the U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see it July 31, 2019 now in the second quarter: You see weak investment, you see weak manufacturing—so support Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL demand there and also to support return of inflation to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But there’s definitely an insurance aspect of it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Trade is unusual.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t—you know, the thing is, there isn’t a lot of experience in responding to global trade tensions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it is a—it’s something that we haven’t faced before and that we’re learning by doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it is not—it’s not exactly the same as watching global growth, where you see growth weakening, you see central banks and governments responding with fiscal policy, and you see growth strengthening, and you see a business cycle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With trade tensions—which do seem to be having a significant effect on financial market conditions and on the economy—they evolve in a different way, and we have to follow them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, I want to be clear here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We play no role whatsoever in assessing or evaluating trade policies other than as—as trade policy uncertainty has an effect on the U.S. economy in the short and medium term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not in any way criticizing trade policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s really not our job.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Nick Timiraos of the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: So, Chair Powell, you and your colleagues have offered three reasons to cut rates: a lower neutral rate that may have made policy a little bit tighter than anticipated, the global slowdown and the darker risk picture from the trade tensions, and this desire to re-center inflation and inflation expectations.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: I wonder, which of those factors, if any, weighs most heavily on you?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And, more importantly, is a ¼ point cut really going to address all of that, let alone any one of those?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I actually think different people have different—different weightings has been my experience on those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You mentioned lower r*, trade slowdown—and I would actually add, lower natural rate of unemployment too has moved down, all of which July 31, 2019 kind of point to more accommodation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, again, I don’t think asking about a ¼ point is really Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the right question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think you have to look back over the course of the year and see the Committee moving away from rate increases to a neutral posture to, now, a rate cut.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think we’ve been providing—and that affects the forward rate path, and it affects financial conditions, and financial conditions affect the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see an economy which is actually performing pretty well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Growth in the first half of this year is about the same as it was in all of ’18 and actually a little better than our forecast for growth in 2019—at the end of 2019.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think, in a way, that’s monetary policy working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, I wouldn’t just look at the 25 basis point cut as the right question.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: If I could follow up, I guess in May—in May it seemed as if you were setting a higher bar to cut rates: There would need to be a deterioration in the outlook.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: In June, you seemed to suggest that if the outlook didn’t improve, there might be a rate cut.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Where is that bar right now, because I think there’s some confusion about how the Committee is responding.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we, as we noted—we noted at the bottom of the statement that language, which really says how we’re thinking about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it says, as we’re contemplating the future path of the target range for the federal funds rate, we’ll continue to monitor the implications of incoming information—and it talks about that language.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, I can’t—all I can tell you is, we’ll be looking at weak global growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be looking very carefully to see how that’s happening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think you see—you learn—every cycle you learn about these things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we will see whether growth is picking up, whether it’s bottoming out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll see that picture.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll also see on trade.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’re going to be seeing—I think we’ve learned a lot on trade in this July 31, 2019 cycle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’ll continue to learn more, and on inflation we will.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in addition, the U.S.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL economy itself is—the performance of the U.S. economy will enter into that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would love to be more precise, but with trade, it is a factor that we have to assess in kind of a new way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those are the things that we’ll be looking at, and—you know, in making our decisions going forward.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Edward Lawrence with Fox Business Network.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So a rate hike last December was seen by some economists and the St. Louis Fed president, James Bullard, as a step too far.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Now the Fed’s waited about seven months for a rate cut.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: You said today you were concerned about downside risks.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So could some of the weakness on the business side, with that fixed investment and the sluggish side on the business side, be because the Fed waited so long?

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: I want to get your thoughts on that and talk about why you feel that this nudge is the right level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we don’t hear that from businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They don’t come in and say, “We’re not investing because, you know, the federal funds rate is too high.” I haven’t heard that from a business.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What you hear is that demand is weak for their products.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see manufacturing being weak all over the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Investment—business investment is weak.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I wouldn’t lay all of that at the door of trade talks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think there’s a—there’s a global business cycle happening with manufacturing and investment, and that’s—that’s been, you know, definitely a bigger factor than, certainly, we expected late last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think global—global growth started to slow down in the middle of last year, but that has gone on to a greater extent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, trade policy uncertainty has also been, I think, more elevated than we anticipated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of, is this the—we believe this is the right move for today, and we think it’s—we think it will serve the three ends that I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ve already gone over how we’re thinking about going forward.

speaker: ANN SAPHIR
sentence: Ann Saphir with Reuters.

speaker: ANN SAPHIR
sentence: You called it “a midcycle adjustment to policy.” And, I mean, what should we take this to mean, and what message do you mean to send with this move today about future rate moves?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, the sense of that is—I mean, that refers back to other times when the FOMC has cut rates in the middle of a cycle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’m contrasting it there with the beginning—for example, the beginning of a lengthy cutting cycle.

speaker: ANN SAPHIR
sentence: So we’re not at the beginning of a lengthy cutting cycle?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is not—that’s not what we’re seeing now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s not our perspective now or outlook.

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: Hi there.

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: Are there any circumstances under which you would decide to pause—pause at one interest rate cut, today’s interest rate cut, and not—not, not go ahead with further monetary easing at this stage?

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: Or are you predicting that, you know, once you’ve embarked on this easing, you will have to at least move by one more notch going forward?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, so our policy is—will depend on the implications of incoming data for the economic outlook as well as evolving risks to that outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we’re going to be monitoring the implications of incoming information for the outlook, as I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, so I—that’s really where I would leave you with that.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Hi.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Victoria Guida with Politico.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: On capital, Vice Chairman Quarles has said that the level of capital requirements that exists right now are such that it’s basically like the countercyclical capital buffer is already turned on, and that he would like the ability to be able to turn it down in a downturn.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: I was wondering if you agreed with that.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: And then, also, just quickly, on real-time payments—larger banks have suggested that if the Fed built its own system, that would be a bait-and-switch, because the Fed asked—or called for a private-sector system.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Do you think that that is a fair assessment?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on the first, I would say that I view the level of capital requirements and the level of capital in the system as being about right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do agree with that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The idea that you’re talking about is one that’s—that Vice Chair Quarles has talked about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a—it’s one under consideration.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The idea being, in a sense, we’ve chosen, in the United States, to have high through-the-cycle capital requirements by doubling the SIFI surcharge, which is the surcharge that the largest banks have in their capital requirements.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve, in effect, already put in place substantial countercyclical buffers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so, conceptually, you can think of—I’m not saying it’s the same thing as a countercyclical capital buffer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s—that’s really the point—is that we don’t rely—our system doesn’t rely on our ability—it doesn’t mainly rely on our ability to identify the right time in the cycle to trigger a countercyclical tool.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We rely on through-the-cycle, always-on high capital and liquidity requirements.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think that’s a good thing to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The idea of putting it in place so you can cut it, that’s something some other jurisdictions have done, and it’s worth considering.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the United Kingdom, in particular, has a countercyclical capital buffer that’s always on, but the one point of it is that you can cut when there’s a downturn and therefore give the banks more room.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this isn’t something we’ve decided to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just under consideration.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the real-time payment system, your second question, so this is something we—the United States is far behind other countries in terms of having real-time payments available to the general public.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed, really, coming out of the Reserve System—the Reserve Banks and the Board together—convened all of the stakeholders around the table to talk about July 31, 2019 how we can move forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is consumer groups, technology companies, banks, card Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL companies—pretty much all of the groups who would be interested—and worked on a project for several years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And one of the things that came out of that was a recommendation that the Fed should build a 24 x 7 x 365 real-time settlement system to solve that problem—to address that problem.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We put out a proposal in October of last year about, you know, should we do this, and we got quite a lot of comments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They were overwhelmingly favorable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would point out that in our payment system, in many places, the Fed operates alongside private-sector operators—for example, in wholesale payments, in ACH, and in check—so it wouldn’t be unusual or out of keeping with—with how we’ve done things in the past.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have not made a decision on this, but it’s something we’re looking at carefully and something I do expect we’ll make a decision on soon.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: Craig Torres from Bloomberg.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: I’m trying to parse what you’re saying here.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: On the one hand, you say the policy tilt in the statement has eased financial conditions, and that’s helping the economy.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: In that tilt, market participants are interpreting this language, “will act as appropriate,” as still being in the statement.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: And, on the other hand, you say it’s not the start of a—of an easing cycle.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: So what are you saying?

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: Does that mean, you know, with one or two more cuts you’ll be done, and this policy bias comes out of the statement?

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: Or simply that this policy bias will come out of the statement sooner than market participants think?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it is—as I mentioned, it’s going to depend on the evolving data and the evolving risk picture.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But as we look at the situation now and the outlook now, what we see is that it’s appropriate to make an adjustment in policy to a somewhat more accommodative July 31, 2019 stance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we’re seeing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s what we’re going to be looking—you know, we’ll Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL be looking at incoming data, at all of the—at the risks that I mentioned, and the performance of the U.S. economy, and at low inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be looking at that to make our decisions going forward.

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: Scott Horsley for NPR.

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: You’ve talked a number of times about the people who feel like they are just recently getting to the punchbowl 10 years into this expansion.

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: Can you elaborate a little bit on how this rate cut is expected to help them?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I think the best thing for people who are—who are feeling that—and we are getting lots of feedback from people who work and live in low- and moderate-income communities to the effect that they’re now feeling the recovery, and, in fact, they haven’t felt a better labor market in anybody’s memory, so this is great to hear.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I guess my view is, the best thing we can do for those people is to sustain the expansion, keep it going, and that’s one of the overarching goals of—of this move and all of our policy moves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There really is no reason why the expansion can’t keep going.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation is not troublingly high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at the—at the U.S. economy right now, there’s no sector that’s booming and therefore might bust.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You have a fairly well-balanced, in a sense, economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, the engine, though, is really a consumer economy, which is 70 percent of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The manufacturing economy—the investment and manufacturing part of the economy—is more or less not—not growing much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s at a healthy level but not growing much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and we hope to help that with this rate cut.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, I would say, overall, we’re trying to sustain the expansion and keep, you know, close to our statutory goals, which are maximum employment and stable prices.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Chairman Powell, Donna Borak with CNN.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: The President has repeatedly called for this rate hike and for the Fed to end the runoff of its balance sheet.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: What do you say to those that say that the Fed gave into what the President wanted today?

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: And could you also elaborate a little bit further on why the Fed decided to speed up its balance sheet runoff two months earlier today?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I gave my—my reasons for—our reasons, really—for doing this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, just to touch on that again, this action is designed to insure against downside risks to the outlook from weak global growth and trade tensions, offset the negative effect that those factors are already having, and promote a faster return of inflation to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we’ve been talking about all year long, and we’ve gradually moved our policy in the direction of more accommodation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think what you see is an economy that has reacted well to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s what we’re doing, and that’s why we’re doing it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We never take into account political considerations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s no place in our discussions for that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also don’t conduct monetary policy in order to prove our independence.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We conduct monetary policy in order to—to move as close as possible to our statutory goals, and that’s what we’re always going to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re always going to use our tools that way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then, at the end, we’ll—you know, we’ll live with the results.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the balance sheet, that was really just a matter of simplicity and consistency.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Really nothing more to it than that.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you, Chairman Powell.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Greg Robb from MarketWatch.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: I was wondering—we weren’t in the room, but I think it’s a fair assumption to know that the two dissenters probably spoke about financial stability concerns.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: So I was wondering if you could talk about what you—what was your response to them when those concerns were raised?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: I’ve July 31, 2019 collected a couple of things from the IMF, and the Bank of International Settlements said that it’s Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL just—when you have low rates, you just get more debt in the economy, and that there’s also this feeling that it makes it harder to raise rates.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: So could you talk about that?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, first, let me say—I’ll just speak for myself, but I understand those concerns very well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve—you know, I’ve studied them, I’ve spoken about them, and I take them very seriously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But as I look at today’s situation, I don’t see them as a reason not to take this action today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I just don’t think—that would be my point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And one of the reasons why I think that is, if you look—if you look—so we have a financial stability framework now for the first time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Before the crisis, we didn’t have this, but now we have it, and we publish it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we look at, really, four big things so that we know we can—you know, the public can hold us accountable and compare us meeting to meeting, and—you know, and see whether we got this right, because it’s transparent now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the four things we look at are valuation pressures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we do see notable valuation pressures in some markets but, you know, honestly, not at a highly troubling level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of household borrowing, household and business borrowing is the second thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Households are in a very good shape overall.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ll come back to business borrowing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Leverage in the financial system is low, and funding risk is low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, overall, staff’s view has been—and my view has been—that if you look overall, financial stability vulnerabilities are moderate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The place that gets all the attention right now—a lot of attention—is business borrowing, and we look very carefully at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What’s happening with business borrowing is, the loans have moved off the balance sheets of the banks and into market-based vehicles, which tend to be stably funded.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, nonetheless, it’s clear that the highly leveraged business sector could act as an amplifier to a downturn.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re watching that very carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, again, I think if you July 31, 2019 look overall at the U.S. financial system, what you see is a high level of resilience—much higher Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL than it was before the crisis—and that’s something to take comfort from.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think all of that gives us the ability to use monetary policy for its purposes and rely on supervisory and regulatory tools to—you know, to keep the financial system resilient.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: So you’re not doing something today for—to help today, and then it’s going to cause problems down the road?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: You’re not worried about that kind of dynamic?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are very few things that I don’t worry about at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, of course, of course, we monitor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have—every quarter we have an extensive briefing on financial stability, and we had that yesterday.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we look at this on an ongoing basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have a great team.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We liaise with central banks around the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, one of my colleagues is the head of the Financial Stability Board globally, so we’re very, very much monitoring these things all the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we worry about them all the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re always looking at the—we’re looking for that thing that we may have missed a lot of the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the things we haven’t missed, I think they paint a mixed picture, but not one that should prevent us from taking monetary policy actions that we think are appropriate to support the economy.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: Marty Crutsinger, AP.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: You’ve talked in this press conference about being data dependent going forward, and that this is not the start of a series of rate cuts.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: But the financial markets seem to think that this is the start of a series of rate cuts, and they’re predicting three, four cuts this year.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: Is this your effort to try to damp down that—that thing?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let me be clear.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What I said was, it’s not—it’s not the beginning of a long series of rate cuts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I didn’t—I didn’t say it’s just one or anything like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What I said is, when you think about rate-cutting cycles, they go on for a long time, and the July 31, 2019 Committee is not seeing that—not seeing us in that place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You would do that if you saw real Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL economic weakness and you thought that the federal funds rate needed to be cut a lot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s not what we’re seeing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s not what we’re seeing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we’re seeing is that it’s appropriate to—to adjust policy to a somewhat more accommodative stance over time, and that’s how we’re looking at it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What I said was, it’s not a long cutting cycle—in other words, referring to what we do when there’s a recession or a very severe downturn.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s—that’s really what I was ruling out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think, if you look back at other midcycle adjustments, you’ll see—you know, I don’t know that they’ll be, in the end, comparable or not, but you’ll see examples of these.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: Don Lee with the L.A. Times.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: You mentioned the difficulty of assessing trade tensions in the economic outlook.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: Could you say how much of a factor the U.S.–China trade conflict was in the Fed’s decision to cut rates?

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: And if the current stalemate and the threat of more tariffs continue, what would that mean for future interest rates and possible cuts?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, I wouldn’t bring it down to any one trade thing or any one factor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we look at a broad range of factors, and trade uncertainty—trade policy uncertainty is one of them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That certainly includes the discussions with China, but I wouldn’t—I wouldn’t be able to tell you how much of it is due to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And without knowing—you know, I think we—with trade, we have to react to the developments, and we don’t know what they’ll be, and so it’s hard to exactly say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Certainly, we’ve seen, though, that when there’s a sharp confrontation between two large economies, you can see effects on business confidence pretty quickly and on financial markets pretty quickly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We saw that in June.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But then we saw them unwind after that, to some extent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’ve seen it returning to—to a much lower temperature, I July 31, 2019 think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, with—with trade policy, we’re just going to be watching and trying to assess the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL implications for the—for the U.S. outlook.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: How much of an effect could the tariffs have?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the mechanical effects of the tariffs are quite small.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re not large as it relates to the U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The real question is, what are the effects on the economy through the—through the confidence channel—business confidence channel?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, very, very hard to tease that out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve seen some research, which—you know, which says that they are meaningful—meaningful effects on—on output.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s to say, not trivial.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think that that sounds right, but it’s quite hard to get—there is no way to get an accurate measure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You have to look at a range of estimates, and I think businesses will tell you that it’s a factor, particularly businesses that have—manufacturing businesses that have supply chains that cross international borders will all tell you that it’s been a challenge.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many of them have made adjustments, and they’ve gotten to a place where it’s okay, but it’s—it’s been a challenge.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: Paul Kiernan from Dow Jones Newswires.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: Thanks for the question, Chairman.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: As the press conference—as this press conference has gone under way, markets have declined.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: The Dow is down as much as 400 points.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: What I’m hearing is a reluctance to provide more guidance around the future path of rates.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: And I’m wondering if that reflects a greater lack of consensus on the Committee.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: And, you know, how much consensus do you want to see around these decisions, and how split are people about this?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, you’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a range of views on the Committee, and—but the Committee is unified, completely unified on our dedication to making the best policy decisions that we can make.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that means people have a responsibility to do their best thinking and to present that thinking, and I wouldn’t have it any other way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the way forward, we will be monitoring the factors that I mentioned, and we laid that out in the—you know, in the postmeeting statement, and that’s the roadmap we’re going to be following going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to be data dependent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to be, as we always are, doing what we need to do—what we believe we need to do to support the economic expansion.

speaker: JOHN HELTMAN
sentence: Hi, John Heltman with American Banker.

speaker: JOHN HELTMAN
sentence: So it’s been about 18 months since the Fed issued its enforcement action against Wells Fargo.

speaker: JOHN HELTMAN
sentence: And I was wondering if you could characterize the progress that the bank has made towards the shortcomings that it had in its risk-management processes.

speaker: JOHN HELTMAN
sentence: And I’m also curious whether their lack of a permanent CEO has hampered progress, in your eyes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the problems at Wells Fargo—that arose at Wells Fargo around risk management and consumer—the way they dealt with the consumer were actually pretty deep, and I think the company realizes that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they’re not going to be fixed—they haven’t been fixed quickly, and, frankly, we didn’t expect them to be fixed quickly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So they’re—you know, they—they will be under the growth cap, our enforcement action, until the Board votes to lift it, and that’s not something we’re considering doing right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the Committee—I mean, the company is working away to address these issues, but, as I said, they’re deep-seated issues, and it just takes time to address them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t comment on the CEO question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t really have anything for you on that.

speaker: JOHN HELTMAN
sentence: I mean, I just—I’d like to clarify, like, are you pleased with the responsiveness you’re getting from them?

speaker: JOHN HELTMAN
sentence: Do you feel like this is going the way that you kind of wanted it to go?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not going to characterize it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know—I mean, I have characterized it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have—we have an enforcement action in place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The company is working away at addressing it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They take it seriously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think they do see it as we do, as something that has to go deep.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’ll lift the growth cap when we’re satisfied.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Nancy Marshall-Genzer with Marketplace.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: So when we have our next recession, the Fed will have less room—it will happen—the Fed will have less room to maneuver cutting interest rates since you’re cutting now.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: How big of a problem will that be?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the premise is not—I will question your premise for a second.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you remember whether—again, one of the purposes of our—of our cut today is to support the expansion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t know when—and if it really works—if that works very well and the economy gets going again, you know, you don’t know where the—where the funds, in other cycles—and I don’t know whether this will happen or not, but in other cycles, the Fed wound up raising rates again after a midcycle adjustment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, I’m not predicting that, but I don’t think that we know that we won’t have—that we’ll have less ammo because of these things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s one thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So— NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you won’t be able to cut as much if—if rates are low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, you will have—have less ammo, in that sense.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, but you’re assuming that we would never raise rates again, that once we’ve cut these rates that they can never go back up again.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Just as a matter of principle, I don’t think that’s right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In other—in other long, long cycles, long U.S. business cycles have sometimes involved this kind of event where the Fed will stop hiking—in fact, will cut—and then will go back to hiking.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, I don’t know whether that’ll happen right here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It doesn’t July 31, 2019 seem—it doesn’t seem like something that’s in—you know, particularly likely, frankly, but we Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL don’t know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the other thing is, I think by extending the cycle, you—you do have a lot of benefits from that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think, you know, we will use the tools that we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A couple of rate hikes one way or the other isn’t going to matter so much if there is a downturn.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’re right, there will eventually be one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll use all of our tools aggressively, as we need to, when that time comes.

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: Hi, Jean Yung with MNI.

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: Can you give us an update on the ongoing reassessment of the inflation framework?

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: And have the discussions so far this year had any bearing on today’s decision?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the monetary policy review is really for—it’s really there to look at the way we make policy in the longer run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not something that enters directly into our discussions today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve had—so far we’ve had a series of meetings, called Fed Listens, at almost all the Reserve Banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Soon it will be all the Reserve Banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we meet there with the constituencies that we serve, and they’ve been very, very successful, hearing from people—not just—not just economists, but people who are not economists, how—how their lives interact with the Fed’s work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s been—it’s been great.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve got to say, it’s been even better than I hoped it would be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re just now beginning the process of incorporating all of that feedback, and we’re going to be having a series of meetings, beginning today and yesterday, as we evaluate, you know, the questions that we’re asking about our framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s very early to say where that’s going, but, you know, we’re setting the table now and looking at what our framework is July 31, 2019 and looking at how it’s performed, looking at how all frameworks performed around the world Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL during the Global Financial Crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I expect we’ll be at this a while.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m very excited about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s been a good exercise.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s opened us up to sunlight and perspectives that we might not have gotten otherwise.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think it’s a good time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, you have—10 years after the crisis, you’re really living in a new normal for the economy and monetary policy, and it’s a really good time to step back and ask whether there are some things that we can do to improve our framework.

speaker: COURTENAY BROWN
sentence: Hi, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: COURTENAY BROWN
sentence: Courtenay Brown from Axios.

speaker: COURTENAY BROWN
sentence: Can you give us a sense of whether the Committee feels constrained at all by the market’s expectations for more cuts or other developments in financial markets?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think this was—this was well telegraphed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we did today was—was very consistent with what we had said we were going to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I had mentioned the reasons for it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’ve been well telegraphed, and I think—you know, I think they will—they will achieve their goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do know that monetary policy works through communications and then actions that are consistent with those communications, and we think that the changes that we’ve made this year have really worked.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we always retain the flexibility to adjust our communications and our actions to—in light of incoming data and the evolving risk picture, but—I’ll leave it there.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Hi, Brian Cheung with Yahoo Finance.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Just to expand on that point about communication, I mean, we saw that markets have been particularly sensitive with regards to New York Fed President John Williams’s remarks before the blackout period.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: So the Fed added language in the statement that says that the Committee is contemplating the future path of July 31, 2019 the target range for the federal funds rate as it monitors implications.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: I’m wondering—now Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL there’s kind of this inflection point about whether or not the downside risk, because you’ve had to cut rates, outweighs the fact that you still see a positive outlook of the U.S. economy at a baseline.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: So, just wondering if you can kind of clarify all those things within the context of the challenges of communicating it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah, so again, I see the U.S. outlook as being a positive one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we do—we have had these global, really, risks to the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There really—there really is nothing in the U.S. economy that presents a—you know, a prominent near-term threat to the U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, there’s no—there’s no segment that’s really—or sector that’s really boiling over and overheating.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nothing like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—it’s within—within the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—it’s healthy, so I would say that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Downside risks are really coming from abroad.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, we are concerned about—about low inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But—and, by the way, those risks from abroad are affecting the manufacturing sector here and business investment—fixed investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—thank you.
